subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quickscript in the NYTimes?
msgSnippet: The Hebrew cursive handwriting predates the establishment of the state of Israel. The printed style is based on the Aramaic square script, but the handwriting
messageBody:
The Hebrew cursive handwriting predates the establishment
of the state of Israel. The printed style is based on the Aramaic
square script, but the handwriting is based on an older, more
primitive form of the alphabet and resembles the Phoenecian
in many regards, so it must have been around for a long time.
Note, for example, that ayin has a loop and resembles our
letter "O," which is derived ultimately from the Phoenecian
ayin. The ayin in the square script doesn't look like that at
all.

Gary Yu

Alexander Lampros wrote:

>kick fucking ass. Hmmm....anyone know when cursive
>Hebrew was devoloped? Has it existed for ever and a
>day, or is it something that was devoloped by the
>Israeli state in 1946?
>
>Yours,
>
>Alex
>
>

The Hebrew cursive handwriting predates the establishment
of the state of Israel. The printed style is based on the Aramaic
square script, but the handwriting is based on an older, more
primitive form of the alphabet and resembles the Phoenecian
in many regards, so it must have been around for a long time.
Note, for example, that ayin has a loop and resembles our
letter "O," which is derived ultimately from the Phoenecian
ayin. The ayin in the square script doesn't look like that at
all.

Gary Yu
